stories.text:
Most of my career has been working with older existing systems. Many have struggled to stay up to date. With desktop applications that's not a huge problem, but with web applications they die. I've seen this with a brilliant system that had a Flex (Adobe flash derivative) front end. It got killed.

I've seen this with front ends written in ExtJS, it's just so old now that maintaining it is a pain. The same thing with old versions of Zend. PHP 5.6 is no longer supported but most operating systems out of the box so we have to find an upgrade path.

Has anyone found a stack that lasts? Or a method of avoiding this sort of thing?
stories.title: Ask HN: How to pick tech with Longevity?

stories.text:
This may be a bit outside HN norm.

I’ve been blessed/cursed with a couple of young cats that are entirely too smart, energetic and curious for my or their good.

I’m starting to work on a automated laser pointer controlled by motors/RPi, but that’s taking time.

Are there commercially available toys that are good for bored, intelligent, energetic young felines?
stories.title: Ask HN: Toys for pets that are too smart

stories.text:
How do I set up IIS to debug classic ASP?

Help Needed Setting up Classic ASP Debugging

According to what I have seen on social media, in order for me to set up my computer for writing and debugging Classic ASP, I need to set up IIS a certain way -- which I did -- and then I have to enable ASP by doing the following:

IIS7 - IIS > ASP > Compilation > Debugging Properties > Enable Server-side Debugging

And I am stuck on this. Please, someone give me an idea of what I need to click on.

https://i.stack.imgur.com/xOwwt.png
stories.title: How do I set up IIS to debug classic ASP?
